entry.title: Reland "Add notifyEvent API for fenced frames."
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit 62f8e1eb2e54597cacc165645e888c6b89229826



The revert was due to a flake in notify-event-invalid.https.html, which I believe is due to an excessive wait in the test. I reduced the wait, and added the timeout tag just in case. I also added some absl::optional -> std::optional conversions so that Gerrit presubmits would pass. Also caught a WPT bug in which the test was still passing even though one of the origins was undefined, so I fixed that too.



Original change's description:

> Add notifyEvent API for fenced frames.

>

> This API allows DOM events that occur within a fenced frame

> to be observed by the frame's embedder in a privacy-respecting manner.

> When an eligible event type (currently, just click) occurs within

> the embedded document, window.fence.notifyEvent(e) can be called

> with the event object, which will create a censored version of

> the event to be handled by the embedder via addEventListener().

>

> This API is being implemented as part of the "fenced frames with

> local unpartitioned data access" proposal, see explainer here:

> https://github.com/WICG/fenced-frame/blob/master/explainer/fenced_frames_with_local_unpartitioned_data_access.md

>

> Design doc for this CL is here:

> https://docs.google.com/document/d/1EiysMPnARSx2pzI1hSeFlI7k2ETxs5ycZoV2Cy08PEk/edit?usp=sharing

>

> Bug: 1515579

> Change-Id: I7f155e5640e7b798ca33a48c6afdda9c039d45c0

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5166147

> Reviewed-by: Alex Moshchuk

> Commit-Queue: Andrew Verge

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1260541}



Bug: 1515579

entry.title: [FedCM] Show the newly logged in account on desktop
entry.content:
We plumb the account IDP info to the desktop UI code. We then invoke

the single account chooser UI to show the newly logged in account. If

there are more accounts, a back button is added which takes the user to

a multi account chooser. Some members are plumbed correctly in the

ShowFailureDialog() case as otherwise the title is incorrect in the edge

case that the user starts with no accounts, clicks login, logs in to

multiple accounts at once, and clicks the back button to see both (by

default, only one account is shown in this case in the initia UI after

logging in).

entry.title: Refactor Attribution Internals data model
entry.content:
- Replace TableModel abstraction with data-binding on row elements: This

allows us to avoid re-rendering rows during sorting.

- Update rows in place for sources and reports tables: In a followup

change this will allow us to highlight rows that changed.

- Apply ARIA attributes for selectability.

- Replace custom event listeners with standard event dispatch.

- Use 1 event listener per table for selection instead of 1 per row per

table.

- Use 1 event listener per table for sorting instead of 1 per column.



We modify AttributionManagerImpl to issue report-sent notifications

strictly before report-updated notifications to give observers the

chance to maintain sent reports by ID rather than have them seem to

disappear.



Change-Id: Ied136086a8127e3de45579817aeafc978b97c105

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5310954

entry.title: Revert "[OOPIF PDF] Block non-PDF navigation attempts on PDF frames"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 0a37de1c277c2ed67f5e4414dee469bd00d003c0.



Reason for revert: The CL was blocking an internal team.



Original change's description:

> [OOPIF PDF] Block non-PDF navigation attempts on PDF frames

>

> Block navigation attempts on PDF frames that aren't relevant for PDF

> viewer setup by blocking the request in PdfNavigationThrottle. That way,

> compromised renderers won't be able to navigate the PDF frames.

>

> To avoid a dependency violation, PdfNavigationThrottle (which lives in

> //components/pdf) uses a new ShouldCancelPdfFrameNavigation() function

> in PdfStreamDelegate that ChromePdfStreamDelegate (which lives in

> //chrome/browser/pdf) overrides to block these navigations.

>

entry.title: Add a11y manifest outputs as data
entry.content:
Currently the targets using the template are defined as deps,

which means they're only used for compile. But that's not

correct because we do use them when running Chrome. It didn't

cause issue before because:

1 When we run tests locally, we don't rely on this deps because

everything is generated locally. As long as the outputs set

correctly it would work.

2 For files release to users, we manually select which files we

pack. e.g. for lacros it's defined here:

https://source.corp.google.com/h/chrome-internal/codesearch/chrome/src/+/main:internal/testing/buildbot/archive/lacros64.json;l=32;drc=c97d26d60062ffddaf0c495b0710f2c9b04c5df4



We recently set up a Lacros internal builder which exposed this

issue. It's because on bot, we rely on data/data_deps to figure

out which files are needed when running tests. These files would

be copied from compiler bot to tester bot to run tests. Now tests

failed with missing files because those files were not copied.



Fixing the issue by adding the output as data. This change should

not affect production because we don't rely on data field to pick

which files we release.



This change fixes all tests on tryjob



Test: Currently with failure

https: //ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chrome/builders/ci/linux-lacros-chrome/146/overview

https: //ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chrome/builders/try/linux-lacros-chrome/7/overview

entry.title: Add extension installation without parent approval for child users
entry.content:
This change adds a new mode of handling extensions when installing

a new extension. It consumes the preference

`kSkipParentApprovalToInstallExtensions` and skips

the parent approval step, granting by default a parent approval

at the end of the installation when the the pref is enabled.

Otherwise it requests the parental approval.

The corresponding cases in the webstore_private_apitest are

adjusted for the new mode, and a new case for skipping approval

is added.

entry.title: Revert "[TabGroups] Fix sizing of tabs on collapse of a group when adding tab."
entry.content:
This reverts commit 70dd4a0d815b34d85fb84afdbfe24d38aa200d43.



Reason for revert: A result of this change is that new tabs are now animating from an incorrect location when the new tab button is clicked.



Original change's description:

> [TabGroups] Fix sizing of tabs on collapse of a group when adding tab.

>

> ExitTabClosingMode sets some values that are eventually used for aninmation, however the animations are not guaranteed to be performed. In order to make sure that animations occur, AnimateToIdealBounds is called on exiting tab closing mode.

entry.title: Keep track of system level notification permission state for app shims.
entry.content:
Monitor and store in AppShimRegistry the last known state of system

level notification permissions for app shims. The value is updated

on app-shim startup, any time we try to request notification permission,

any time we try to display a notification and at regular intervals.



This will be used in follow-up CLs to display UI to guide the user to

system settings if the system level permission is not consistent with

the chrome level permission.

entry.title: float: Fix crash when using always on top window
entry.content:
Always on top windows are not managed by tablet mode window manager so

use DefaultState. There was an assumption that DefaultState is used

for clamshell only, leading to a crash. This CL removes that assumption.



And for consistency we exit float state when entering always on top, as

currently we cannot enter float state when already always on top.



We may want to address b/325282588 in the future, but for a short term

crash fix, this should be sufficient.



Bug: b/317064996

Test: ash_unittests TabletWindowFloatTest.FloatStateToAlwaysOnTop

entry.title: [focus manager] guard View::AddObserver with View::HasObserver
entry.content:
The largest source of crashes comes from a NOTREACHED in

ObserverList[1].



This is hit in FocusManager::SetFocusedViewWithReason()[2] after

a call to FocusManager::ClearFocus(), which calls the above with

nullptr.



The ideal solution would be to address the reentrancy, perhaps

early returning or a more robust fix at the problematic callsite

itself, as suggested in b/40763787.



However it is not clear whether exiting code relies on this reentrant

behavior. This CL addresses the crash safely by checking to see if

the View observation exists before attempting to add the observer.



Follow up work should add dump-without-crashing logs and begin to

systematically clean up reentrant code and eventually CHECK that

this remains enforced.



[1] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:base/observer_list.h;l=286;drc=f4a00cc248dd2dc8ec8759fb51620d47b5114090



[2] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:ui/views/focus/focus_manager.cc;l=333;drc=341564182474622e33c964e73a69ea8c1e004eb8



Bug: 40763787, 40068046

Change-Id: Ie4ebdfe034ca0108a3d70912c9779af47db5c37b

entry.title: [build] Limit link concurrency of Android official builds
entry.content:
Although {try, ci}/android-official builders use beefy VMs (*-standard-32), it gets killed for OOM often.

This is because each link step (especially solink) may take 30-60GB,

which exceeds `--mem_per_link_gb=20` a lot.

This CL sets --mem_per_link_gb=30 to reduce the concurrency.

It will reduce link concurrency from 5 to 3 on the machine type.



Caveat: lower link concurrency makes build slower. 2h -> 3h

If migrating Siso is sufficient, it's better to keep the concurrency. https://crrev.com/c/5310861



Test:

https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/try/android-official/1200/overview



Cq-Include-Trybots: luci.chromium.try:android-official

Bug: 325280062

entry.title: sensors: Avoid sending too many stashed virtual sensor readings
entry.content:
Follow-up to https://crrev.com/c/5272509: StartSensor() should call

AddReading() only if the virtual sensor is switching state from inactive

to active, otherwise every single call to Sensor.start() ends up

triggering this code path.



The behavior being fixed was not user-visible because

SensorProxyImpl::UpdateSensorReading() in Blink already discards

readings with the same timestamp, but it is still a good idea to avoid

unnecessary function calls.

entry.title: Implement reverse (C++ to JNI) type conversions for @JniType
entry.content:
Now @JniType can annotate the return type of @NativeMethods methods or

the parameter of an @CalledByNative method and it will handle the

conversions in either direction (i.e. std::string <-> JavaRef).



Other changes:

- Changed conversion function names to differentiate the direction

of conversion more easily.

- Converted params are now just a reference instead of a move target

(i.e. std::string& for @JniType("std::string")).

- Improved Jni Zero BUILD.gn documentation and added a section about

@JniType and conversion functions.

entry.title: [AvatarButton] Intro to refactoring the state management
entry.content:
Intrdouce the concept of StateManager and StateProvider.

StateProvider would be linked to an enum value that would show it's

priority compared to other StateProviders.

StateManager would contain all possible states and be able to return

the current state that is active and with the highest priority.



The goal of this design is to have each State manage itself with

the information it needs. Also each State would be completely

independent from another one. It would only have to mark itself as

active or not, for the StateManager to be able to return the correct

active state at each time. Potentially multiple states could be

active at the same time, but only the highest priority one would be

used.



This way each state would be properly scoped and managing itself. It

would be easy to introduce a new state, just by giving it's right

priority through the list in the enum, and a way to activate itself.



Currently, not all the states were migrated to use this logic, so

additional code is needed to make sure the behavior is not altered

during the changes.



In future CLs:

- Make the states be able to request visual updates when their

active state is potentially being changed.

- Adapt the rest of the states to follow this logic.

- [Not sure about this one]: Potentially the StateProvider would be

able to provide more information as well, such as the Text or Color

directly.



Bug: b/324018028

Change-Id: If2da9c853dc35713f1ab9bbf1d4c7266147b2479

entry.title: [fonts][perf] Explicitly leak SimpleFontDatas via a LRU cache.
entry.content:
This adds a strong LRU cache to FontDataCache to retain the most

recently used fonts.



This covers the case where a large amount of DOM is destroyed, and

previously we'd release all the font related objects if the GC kicked

in.



Speedometer3 appears to peak at ~75 objects in the cache.



Results for different cache sizes:



Cache size: 64 | 32 | 16

Speedometer3: +0.9% | +0.5% | +0%



Bug: 41490008

entry.title: [css-scroll-snap-2] Prioritize targeted snap areas
entry.content:
Per step 4 of [1], chromium should give preference to targeted[2] elements when there are multiple aligned options.



Some improvements are made to the test files such as:

(in common.js)

- scrollToAlignedElementsInAxis now detects already being at the scroll

position aligned with the snap targets.

- wrapping verifySelectedSnapTarget in a t.step so that a failure during

the verification doesn't lead to timeouts.

(in scroll_support.js)

- waitForScrollReset now takes x and y params which default to 0,0, so

- tests can now use the function to default to positions other than 0,0.



Bug: 324916797



[1]https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9622#issue-2006578282

[2]https://drafts.csswg.org/selectors/#the-target-pseudo

entry.title: [capture_mode] Move texture target calculation to where it's used
entry.content:
CameraFrameVideoHandler calculates and caches the texture target that it

should use. However, there is no need to do this caching:

* Its buffer usage and format don't change over its lifetime

* Capabilities::texture_target_exception_list, which is checked within

gpu::GetBufferTextureTarget(), always contains the same information

computed by the browser



This CL removes the caching, instead calculating the texture target

where it is used. This paves the way for a followup that instead obtains

the texture target from the ClientSharedImage that is available at that

usage point.



Change-Id: If0339db9ceaa57fd45dd33909b24ecc748f07666
